newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia rubber ends week up, market calm.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia rubber ends week up, market calm.

text.p: Malaysian rubber prices ended the week higher but activity was restrained on the back of a weakening ringgit, traders said.
They said prices could stay stable or fall next week depending on the movement of the ringgit.
The ringgit fell to a three-year low on Friday, hitting 2.6120 at 0900 GMT.
"The prices have gone up quite a lot and I think it should either hold at this level or ease off a bit," said a trader.
Traders said although the fall of the ringgit made Malaysian rubber more competitive against Thai and Indonesian, the depreciation was too fast for the market to grasp.

At the close, the Malaysian Rubber Exchange and Licensing Board (MRELB) quoted the benchmark RSS1 buyer for August at 236 cents (90 U.S. cents) a kg, up two cents from Wednesday's close. The SMR20 buyer for August was up one cent to 237.
The market was closed on Thursday for a religious holiday.
Traders quoted Wednesday price levels, putting the SMR 20 at 241 cents, SMR CV at 295, SMR L at 277, SMR5 at 248, SMR10 at 242 and drum latex at 193.
The INRO's five-day average price strengthened at 184.78 Malaysian/Singapore cents a kg on July 17, compared to 183.85 on July 16. The daily indicator rose to 186.06 from 185.86 previously.
Malaysian-based shipping brokers quoted freight rates for rubber from Malaysia to Rotterdam at $700 per 20-ft container, and $1,400 per 40-ft container.
